title: Figma’s 2025 Upgrades Are Rewriting How Teams Build and Run Design Systems

paragraphs.content: Figma is rolling out a wave of design‑system‑focused upgrades that promise to cut iteration time and reduce the pain of maintaining large libraries. A full rewrite of its design systems architecture now makes actions like updating variables or switching modes 30–60% faster, with heavy state swaps dropping from 3500ms to 350ms in some cases.New authoring tools, including a fullscreen variables modal and drag‑and‑drop reordering of modes and collections without breaking IDs, directly target long‑standing workflow bottlenecks for design system teams.Together with responsive layout enhancements and hidden power features like Smart Selection and conditional prototyping, the updates position Figma as a faster, more resilient foundation for systematized product design.

paragraphs.content: Beyond performance, Figma is tightening the connection between design and code through its new Code Connect UI, which links components to GitHub repositories and uses AI suggestions to map the right files with minimal manual setup.Auto Documentation and the Variables and Styles List widget now generate and update system documentation frames directly on the canvas, turning what was once a static chore into a living, queryable inventory of tokens and styles.At the same time, Figma leadership and industry voices are sketching a future where AI‑assisted systems validate designs in real time, nudge teams back to standards, and act as collaborators rather than static reference libraries.

sections.title: Performance, Variables, and Documentation: The New Backbone of System Workflows

paragraphs.content: Under the hood, Figma’s design systems rewrite consolidates components, variables, and related features onto a single data foundation, yielding dramatic speed gains for everyday system work.According to Figma’s Schema 2025 recap, variable updates and mode switches are now 30–60% faster, and complex state swaps that once took 2500–3500ms have dropped to as low as 350–450ms, particularly in files with thousands of instances.These improvements are already live, giving teams a noticeably more responsive editing experience when working across large, multi‑brand libraries that previously strained performance.

paragraphs.content: On the authoring side, Figma has overhauled how designers create and manage variables and collections, opening a fullscreen modal that surfaces all subscribed collections and supports inline variable creation.Crucially, teams can now drag and drop modes and collections to reorder them while preserving IDs, avoiding the sync breaks and rework that used to accompany rebrands or structural overhauls.To keep systems visible and auditable, Figma’s Auto Documentation feature now generates documentation frames cataloging variables by collection and mode, while the Variables and Styles List widget lets teams pull a live, updatable inventory of tokens onto the canvas at the press of a button.

sections.title: From Design to Code: Integrated Handoff and AI‑Assisted System Governance

paragraphs.content: Figma’s new Code Connect UI is designed to narrow the gap between design and implementation by wiring design tokens and components directly to a team’s codebase.The interface connects Figma to GitHub repositories and introduces AI‑powered suggestions that help teams quickly identify the correct code file to map to each component, even for designers without deep engineering expertise.This approach aims to reduce the maintenance overhead that has historically plagued design systems, where documentation and code drift apart despite shared intentions.

paragraphs.content: Looking ahead, Figma and industry practitioners are framing design systems less as static libraries and more as active collaborators embedded in daily work.Talks at Schema emphasize that “whoever finally bridges the gap between design and code is going to win,” outlining a trajectory where real‑time validation, intent‑aware components, and AI‑driven nudges keep work aligned to system rules as it is created.Best‑practice guides now center Figma variables as the connective tissue of this future, arguing that well‑modeled tokens and modes are what allow both humans and AI tools to interpret and enforce design logic across platforms.
